questions.text: A labourer was stuck in a tunnel for 5 days without food. Which of the following processes serves as the primary source of energy for the brain during this time?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The primary source of energy for the brain after 5 days of starvation is ketone bodies produced through ketogenesis.

  • After a meal rich in carbohydrates, glucose is the main energy source for most tissues. The liver, which usually produces glucose in fasting, shifts to consuming glucose.
  • It stores excess glucose as glycogen (glycogenesis) and uses a small portion for lipid synthesis.
  • Muscle and adipose tissue take up glucose under the influence of insulin, storing it as glycogen in muscle or as triacylglycerol in adipose tissue.
  • Adipose tissue lipolysis is suppressed, reducing fatty acid release. The brain and red blood cells continue to rely on glucose at a constant rate.
  • Any surplus glucose is stored, with plasma insulin rising to promote glycogen and fat storage, and to inhibit lipolysis.
  • Dietary fats appear in circulation as chylomicrons and are stored in adipose tissue or oxidised.
  • Amino acids from protein intake are partly taken up by the liver for protein synthesis, while the rest are used by peripheral tissues. Thus, in the fed state, glucose dominates as the main metabolic fuel, while fat storage is enhanced and protein is conserved.
  • During fasting, hepatic glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis provide glucose and more than 60% of this is used by the brain, while red blood cells consume the rest.
  • Adipose tissue undergoes lipolysis, releasing nonesterified fatty acids and glycerol.
  • Fatty acids become the main fuel for the heart, muscles, and liver, while glycerol serves as a gluconeogenic substrate in the liver.
  • With prolonged fasting, glycogen reserves are depleted, and amino acids from muscle protein breakdown supply carbons for gluconeogenesis. (Option A ruled out)
  • If no alternative glucose source is available, the glycogen reserves in the liver and muscles become depleted after roughly 18 hours of fasting.
  • Fatty acid oxidation in the liver generates acetyl-CoA, which exceeds oxidative capacity and is converted into ketone bodies (acetoacetate, 3-hydroxybutyrate).
  • These ketones are exported to muscle and other tissues, sparing glucose, and in long-term fasting, they supply up to 20% of brain energy needs.
  • To summarise, metabolic fuels in the fed state, late at night or by early morning, when most of the liver's glycogen has been depleted, gluconeogenesis becomes the chief source of blood glucose.
  • If fasting continues into the next day, glucose production through gluconeogenesis remains the main mechanism for maintaining blood sugar. The liver's ability to synthesise and release glucose is therefore essential in both short- and long-term fasting.
  • During fasting, circulating ketone bodies rise significantly, providing an alternative fuel for many tissues, including the brain, once their levels are sufficient. This shift reduces reliance on amino acids for gluconeogenesis, helping conserve vital body proteins. (Option B ruled out)
  • Insulin and glucagon are the key hormones controlling the switch between fed and fasting metabolism.
  • In the fed state, insulin promotes glucose uptake, glycogen synthesis, and lipogenesis while suppressing lipolysis.
  • In fasting, low insulin and high glucagon stimulate glycogen breakdown, gluconeogenesis, and mobilisation of fatty acids.
  • Additional modulation occurs through the sympathetic nervous system and other endocrine signals.
  • Plasma glucose is tightly regulated, as the brain and erythrocytes always require glucose, though the brain can partially adapt to ketone use during prolonged fasting. (Option D ruled out)

choices.text: Sudden rise in insulin followed by a slower, sustained drop in insulin
Continuous increase in insulin until a maximum concentration
Increase in insulin followed by a decrease below the baseline level
Sudden initial increase followed by a delayed but higher and continuing increase in insulin levels

questions.text: Under an experimental condition, blood glucose level is spiked to 2-3 times the normal level and is sustained at this level. Which of the following describes the pattern of insulin levels in the blood?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

If blood glucose levels are spiked to 2-3 times the normal and sustained at the same levels, there will be a sudden initial increase followed by a delayed but higher and continuing increase in insulin levels.

Mechanism of Insulin Secretion:

  • Pancreatic beta cells release insulin primarily in response to elevated blood glucose. These cells contain glucose transporters that allow glucose entry proportional to its blood concentration.
  • Inside the cell, glucose is phosphorylated by glucokinase to glucose-6-phosphate, a key regulatory step. The metabolism of glucose-6-phosphate generates ATP, which inhibits ATP-sensitive potassium channels.
  • Their closure depolarises the beta-cell membrane, opening voltage-gated calcium channels. The resulting calcium influx triggers fusion of insulin-containing vesicles with the membrane, releasing insulin into the bloodstream by exocytosis.
  • While glucose concentration is the primary regulator, amino acids and other factors also influence insulin release. At fasting glucose levels (80-90 mg/100 ml), insulin secretion is minimal.
  • When glucose rises two to three times above normal, insulin secretion sharply increases in two phases.
  • The first occurs within 3-5 minutes, due to the release of preformed insulin, but falls back within 5-10 minutes.
  • The second phase begins after about 15 minutes, peaks in 2-3 hours, and involves both additional release of stored insulin and new insulin synthesis. (Options A, B, and C ruled out)
  • This is shown in the illustration given below.
  • When glucose levels fall back, insulin secretion quickly declines, often within 3-5 minutes.
  • This rapid feedback ensures glucose homeostasis: elevated glucose triggers insulin release, which increases glucose uptake into tissues, thereby lowering blood glucose toward normal.
  • Insulin directs tissues to use carbohydrates for energy while suppressing fat utilisation. In low glucose states, insulin secretion falls and fat becomes the primary energy source, except for the brain.
  • With high glucose, insulin secretion rises, shifting metabolism to glucose use and promoting storage of excess glucose as glycogen in the liver and muscle, and as fat. Thus, insulin determines whether glucose or fat is used for energy at any given time.

questions.text: A patient presents with ataxia, anaemia, and sensory neuropathy. Laboratory tests show elevated total homocysteine and methylmalonic acid levels. Production of which of the following amino acids could be affected?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario of ataxia, anaemia, and sensory neuropathy, along with elevated total homocysteine and methylmalonic acid levels, suggests vitamin B12 deficiency, which affects the production of methionine.

  • The term vitamin B12 is used as a generic descriptor for the cobalamins and for practical purposes, is available only from foods of animal origin, with no plant sources.
  • As a result, strict vegetarians (vegans) are at high risk of deficiency. Though trace amounts may be produced by bacteria on fruit surfaces, nutritional needs are generally met either through animal foods or preparations derived from bacterial fermentation.
  • Absorption of vitamin B12 requires binding to intrinsic factor, a glycoprotein secreted by the stomach's parietal cells.
  • Dietary vitamin B12 is first freed from food proteins by gastric acid and pepsin, then binds to cobalophilin from saliva.
  • In the duodenum, pancreatic enzymes degrade cobalophilin, releasing vitamin B12 so it can bind to intrinsic factor. Pancreatic insufficiency can therefore lead to deficiency due to impaired release of vitamin B12 from cobalophilin.
  • Absorption occurs in the distal ileum via receptors that recognise only the intrinsic factor-vitamin B12 complex, not free vitamin.
  • The vitamin also undergoes enterohepatic circulation, being excreted in bile and reabsorbed in the ileum.
  • Two enzymes require vitamin B12: methylmalonyl-CoA mutase and methionine synthase.
  • The first catalyses the conversion of methylmalonyl-CoA, derived from amino acids and odd-chain fatty acids, into succinyl-CoA.
  • Deficiency impairs this process, causing methylmalonyl-CoA buildup and urinary methylmalonic acid excretion, which can be used as a marker of deficiency.
  • Methionine synthase uses vitamin B12 to convert homocysteine into methionine, and production of methionine is impaired in vitamin B12 deficiency.
  • Deficiency of vitamin B12 also causes functional folate deficiency, known as the "folate trap."
  • This occurs because methionine synthase, a B12-dependent enzyme, is required to convert methyltetrahydrofolate into tetrahydrofolate, the active form needed for DNA synthesis.
  • Without vitamin B12, methyltetrahydrofolate accumulates and cannot be used, producing secondary folate deficiency despite adequate folate levels.
  • The deficiency disrupts folic acid metabolism, leading to impaired DNA synthesis and megaloblastic anaemia.
  • Neurological damage also occurs, with irreversible spinal cord degeneration due to impaired methylation of myelin proteins, specifically linked to methionine deficiency in the nervous system.

Explanation of other options:

Tyrosine (Option A): Phenylalanine hydroxylase converts phenylalanine into tyrosine with tetrahydrobiopterin as a cofactor. When the diet supplies enough of the essential amino acid phenylalanine, tyrosine does not need to be obtained from food and is considered nutritionally nonessential.

Glutamine (Option B): The enzyme glutamine synthetase carries out amidation of glutamate to glutamine and requires ATP and a divalent metal cation such as Mg2+.

Cysteine (Option C): Cysteine is not an essential dietary amino acid because it can be synthesised from methionine, which is essential. Methionine is first converted to homocysteine, which then combines with serine to form cystathionine. The breakdown of cystathionine yields cysteine and homoserine. In vitamin B12 deficiency, since homocysteine production is not impaired, synthesis of cysteine remains unaffected.

questions.text: A patient on long-term hydrochlorothiazide presents with features of heart failure, horizontal nystagmus, and peripheral neuropathy. There is no history of alcohol use or smoking. Which of the following deficiencies can cause this presentation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical vignette of features of heart failure, horizontal nystagmus, and peripheral neuropathy in a patient on long-term hydrochlorothiazide is suggestive of beri-beri caused by thiamine deficiency.

  • Thiamine is essential in energy metabolism, particularly in carbohydrate utilisation. Its active form, thiamin diphosphate, acts as a coenzyme for several multienzyme complexes that catalyse oxidative decarboxylation reactions.
  • These include:
    • Pyruvate dehydrogenase in carbohydrate metabolism.
    • α-Ketoglutarate dehydrogenase in the citric acid cycle.
    • The branched-chain keto acid dehydrogenase, involved in breaking down leucine, isoleucine, and valine.
  • Thiamin diphosphate also serves as the coenzyme for transketolase in the pentose phosphate pathway.
  • Another form, thiamin triphosphate, has a role in nerve function by phosphorylating and activating a chloride channel in nerve membranes.
  • Thiamine deficiency can be aggravated by factors such as alcoholism, prolonged use of diuretics, bariatric surgery, severe vomiting (hyperemesis), and the presence of thiaminase enzymes in certain foods.
  • Thiamin Deficiency can manifest in three major ways:
  • Because thiamin diphosphate is required for pyruvate dehydrogenase, its deficiency blocks the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA. On a high-carbohydrate diet, this leads to elevated blood levels of lactate and pyruvate, potentially causing lactic acidosis, which can be life-threatening.
  • Thiamin status is evaluated by measuring the activity of erythrocyte transketolase.

Explanation of other options:

Selenium (Option B): A lack of trace elements like selenium may lead to the development of cardiomyopathy, heart failure, and striated muscle degeneration.. It has been found to promote specific viral mutations, thereby enhancing their virulence.

Zinc (Option C): Zinc deficiency may result in growth retardation, reduced sense of taste and smell, hair loss, diarrhoea, and shrinkage of the gonads.

Vitamin B12 (Option D): Vitamin B12 deficiency often presents first with numbness in the hands, followed by leg paresthesias and sensory ataxia due to large-fibre sensory loss, along with hyperreflexia and absent Achilles reflexes. Other features include optic atrophy, behavioural changes such as irritability, forgetfulness, dementia, and psychosis, while severe cases may show subacute combined degeneration.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with coarse facial features, organomegaly, corneal opacity, and peripheral neuropathy. A deficiency of the enzyme alpha-L-iduronidase is found. Which of the following is accumulated in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario of coarse facial features, organomegaly, corneal opacity, and peripheral neuropathy, along with a deficiency of alpha-L-iduronidase, describes Hurler syndrome in which dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate accumulate.

  • Proteoglycans are widely distributed in all body tissues, especially in the extracellular matrix (ECM), where they occupy space between cells and interact with structural proteins such as collagen and elastin.
  • These molecules also bind growth factors like TGF-β and adhesive proteins such as fibronectin and laminin, influencing structural organisation and cell behaviour.
  • Their glycosaminoglycan (GAG) chains are polyanionic, attracting cations and water to provide turgor, while their gel-like properties and extended polysaccharide chains act as sieves, restricting large molecules but allowing diffusion of smaller ones, thereby contributing to the large volume of the ECM.
  • GAGs are continuously synthesised and degraded, but their turnover in adult tissues is relatively slow.
  • Their breakdown is carried out by lysosomal hydrolases, including endoglycosidases, exoglycosidases, and sulfatases.
  • When enzyme deficiencies impair this process, mucopolysaccharidoses (MPSs), a group of inherited metabolic disorders, occur.
  • These are typically autosomal recessive and involve the accumulation of GAGs in tissues such as the liver, spleen, bone, skin, and nervous system.
  • Hurler and Hunter syndromes are well-known examples. Hurler syndrome, also known as MPS-I, arises due to alpha-L-iduronidase deficiency, leading to the accumulation of dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate. (Options B, C, and D ruled out)
  • Clinical features include organomegaly, skeletal abnormalities, distinctive facial features, developmental delay, and sensory defects affecting vision, hearing, and the cardiovascular system.
  • Diagnosis may involve urine analysis for GAGs, enzyme assays, and genetic testing, with prenatal diagnosis sometimes possible.
  • The various mucopolysaccharidoses are summarised in the table given below.
  • The term mucolipidosis was introduced for conditions sharing features of mucopolysaccharidoses and sphingolipidoses.
  • In these disorders, such as I-cell disease and pseudo-Hurler polydystrophy, defective enzyme trafficking leads to substrate accumulation.
  • Hyaluronidase is a key enzyme that breaks down hyaluronic acid and chondroitin sulfate by cleaving hexosaminidic linkages, generating oligosaccharides that can be further degraded by other enzymes.
  • A genetic defect in hyaluronidase results in MPS IX (Natowicz syndrome), a rare lysosomal storage disease characterised by the accumulation of hyaluronic acid in the joints.

questions.text: A 10-year-old presents with multiple freckles and hyperpigmentation that worsens with sun exposure. Examination reveals two basal cell carcinomas on the face. Which of the following DNA repair mechanisms is defective?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical features of multiple freckles and hyperpigmentation that worsen with sun exposure, along with basal cell carcinomas, is suggestive of xeroderma pigmentosum, which arises due to defective nucleotide excision repair.

  • DNA repair is vital for preserving genomic stability and preventing the spread of mutations, whether within somatic or germ cells.
  • Since DNA is constantly exposed to chemical, physical, and biological insults, cells require efficient systems for detecting and correcting DNA lesions.
  • Eukaryotic cells possess five principal repair pathways:
    • Nucleotide excision repair (NER)
    • Mismatch repair (MMR)
    • Base excision repair (BER)
    • Homologous recombination (HR)
    • Nonhomologous end-joining (NHEJ).
  • These pathways involve numerous proteins, many of which have counterparts in prokaryotes.
  • Mutations in DNA repair genes often result in human diseases, as summarised in the table below.

Explanation of other options:

Base excision repair (Option A): Base excision repair is associated with MUTYH-associated polyposis.

DNA mismatch repair (Option C): Associated with hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC).

DNA double-strand break repair (Option D): There are two pathways by which double-strand break repair occurs - Nonhomologous end joining and homologous repair. Some disorders associated with this include SCID, ATLD, and Bloom syndrome.

questions.text: A 10-month-old boy presents with recurrent oral lesions and respiratory infections. Laboratory investigations reveal reduced B cell, T cell, and NK cell counts along with reduced adenosine deaminase levels. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis based on the history of recurrent oral lesions and respiratory infections in an infant, along with reduced B cell, T cell, and NK cell counts and adenosine deaminase levels, is suggestive of severe combined immunodeficiency.

Severe combined immunodeficiency is a group of genetically diverse disorders with defects in both humoral and cell-mediated immunity.

Explanation of other options:

Agammaglobulinemia (Option A): Agammaglobulinemia is an X-linked recessive disorder and arises from mutations in the Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) gene, which disrupts signalling from the pre-B cell receptor, leading to failure of B-cell precursors to mature into functional B cells and causing markedly reduced immunoglobulin levels. Clinically, the disorder manifests after about six months of age with recurrent bacterial respiratory infections, susceptibility to certain viral and protozoal infections, absence of plasma cells, underdeveloped lymphoid tissues, and normal T-cell function.

Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency (Option B): Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by misfolded α1-antitrypsin protein, most often the PiZ variant, which accumulates in hepatocytes, leading to endoplasmic reticulum stress and impaired inhibition of neutrophil elastase, resulting in lung and liver damage. Clinically, it may manifest in infancy with severe liver disease progressing to cirrhosis, while pulmonary emphysema develops due to unchecked neutrophil elastase activity.

DiGeorge syndrome (Option C): DiGeorge syndrome arises from developmental failure of the thymus due to defects in the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches, most commonly linked to a 22q11 deletion involving the TBX1 gene. This results in deficient T-cell-mediated immunity, hypocalcemic tetany from absent parathyroids, and congenital malformations of the heart and great vessels, often accompanied by abnormal facial features. Clinically, patients show low T-cell counts, reduced resistance to fungal and viral infections, and depletion of T-cell zones in lymphoid organs, while immunoglobulin levels may be normal or reduced depending on the degree of T-cell deficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following molecular diagnostic tests is useful in syndromic conditions like meningitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Among the given options, the most useful molecular diagnostic test in syndromic conditions is multiplex PCR.

  • Nucleic acid amplification methods, including PCR and transcription-mediated amplification, are widely used for the rapid detection of microorganisms.
  • These molecular tests are now standard for diagnosing infections such as gonorrhea, chlamydia, tuberculosis, and herpes encephalitis.
  • In certain situations, they offer far greater sensitivity than traditional methods, for instance, identifying HSV in cerebrospinal fluid or Chlamydia in urine and genital samples.
  • Additionally, multiplex PCR panels capable of detecting more than 20 different pathogens are currently applied to stool, respiratory secretions, CSF, and positive blood culture broths.
  • Commercially available multiplex panels also allow testing for multiple genes as linked to specific inherited conditions. (Option A ruled out)
  • Examples include panels designed for Brugada syndrome, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and Charcot-Marie-Tooth neuropathy.
  • For numerous syndromes, this panel-based genetic testing approach can be a practical diagnostic tool.

Explanation of other options:

Nested PCR (Option C): Nested PCR enhances the sensitivity and specificity of PCR by using two sets of primers in successive rounds of amplification. The first primer pair amplifies the target sequence, and the second primer set binds to an internal sequence within the first product, thereby confirming its identity. Although this method improves detection, it carries a higher risk of contamination during transfer, which can be minimised by physical separation or closed-tube protocols.

Arbitrarily primed PCR (Option D): Arbitrarily primed PCR (AP-PCR) is a technique used to create distinctive DNA fingerprint patterns by employing a single randomly chosen primer under low-stringency conditions. This allows the primer to bind to genomic regions with full or partial homology, producing amplification products when two such sites lie within a few thousand base pairs on opposite DNA strands. The method is also known as random amplified polymorphic DNA (RAPD) PCR or DNA-amplified fingerprinting (DAF) PCR.

Reference:

  1. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC101479/

choices.text: Partial loss of protein and function
Complete loss of protein and function
No change in function as it will be removed in post-translational modification

questions.text: A frameshift mutation was introduced into the coding sequence of an mRNA. If this occurs at the 4th position in an mRNA with 900 nucleotides, which of the following is most likely to happen?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The effect of a frameshift mutation occurring at the 4th position in an mRNA with 900 nucleotides would be the complete loss of protein and function.

  • Frameshift mutations occur when nucleotides are inserted or deleted from a gene in numbers not divisible by three, shifting the reading frame of mRNA and producing garbled protein sequences.
  • Such changes often result in nonsense codons, premature termination, or abnormal amino acid chains, though deletion or insertion in multiples of three simply removes or adds specific amino acids without altering the reading frame.
  • In the given scenario, since the frameshift mutation is occurring at a relatively earlier position, complete loss of protein and function is more likely. (Options A, B, and D ruled out)
  • Sometimes, a combination of insertions and deletions can restore the reading frame but still create partially abnormal proteins, a mechanism implicated in several human diseases.
  • The effects of insertions and deletions using a few examples are illustrated below.
  • Other types of mutations include single-base alterations, known as point mutations, which can be either transitions (a pyrimidine replaced by another pyrimidine or a purine by another purine) or transversions (a purine replaced by a pyrimidine or vice versa).
  • When such DNA changes occur in protein-coding regions, they are transcribed into mRNA, carrying the altered base to the corresponding site.
  • These mutations can have several effects: some may be silent, especially when occurring at the third codon position, where wobble reduces impact, resulting in no change to the protein.
  • Others may cause a missense mutation, leading to the substitution of one amino acid with another. Depending on the substitution, this may be harmless, partially disruptive, or completely detrimental to protein function.
  • In cases where the substitution is partially acceptable, the protein may retain some but abnormal activity, while unacceptable substitutions prevent normal functioning.
  • A more severe outcome occurs when the mutation introduces a nonsense codon, leading to premature termination of translation, producing truncated proteins that usually lack proper function.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman who underwent ileal resection presents with features of anaemia despite a balanced diet. Her RBC count is 2.8 million/mm3, and serum iron is 164 mcg/dL. Which of the following is most likely to be found in her?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical scenario of anaemia with reduced RBC count and normal serum iron in a patient after ileal resection is suggestive of megaloblastic anaemia due to vitamin B12 deficiency.

  • Megaloblastic anaemia arises due to defective DNA synthesis, which results in ineffective blood cell production and distinct morphological abnormalities, notably the presence of unusually large erythroid precursors and red cells.
  • The main subtypes include pernicious anaemia, caused by vitamin B12 deficiency, and folate deficiency anaemia.
  • Both vitamin B12 and folic acid act as coenzymes in the synthesis of thymidine, a DNA base, and their deficiency disrupts DNA synthesis, leading to defective nuclear maturation and delayed or blocked cell division.
  • Other causes of megaloblastic anaemia are summarised in the table below.
  • Peripheral blood typically shows macrocytic and oval-shaped red cells (macro-ovalocytes), which are larger than normal and may appear hyperchromic but lack central pallor.
  • Neutrophils are often larger and display nuclear hypersegmentation with five or more lobes instead of the usual three to four, as shown below.
  • The marrow is usually hypercellular due to an increase in hematopoietic precursors, with megaloblastic changes evident at all stages of erythroid development.
  • Despite delayed nuclear maturation, cytoplasmic growth and haemoglobin synthesis proceed normally, producing nuclear-cytoplasmic asynchrony.
  • Vitamin B12 obtained from the diet is initially released from food proteins through the action of gastric acid and pepsin, after which it attaches to salivary cobalophilin.
  • In the duodenum, pancreatic enzymes break down cobalophilin, liberating vitamin B12 so it can then bind to intrinsic factor. If pancreatic function is impaired, this release step is defective, resulting in vitamin B12 deficiency. Absorption finally takes place in the terminal ileum, where receptors specifically recognise the intrinsic factor-vitamin B12 complex, but not the free vitamin itself. Hence, ileal resection leads to vitamin B12 deficiency and, in turn, megaloblastic anaemia.

Explanation of other options:

Iron deficiency anaemia (Option A): Causes of iron deficiency include inadequate dietary intake, defective absorption, heightened physiological demand, or persistent blood loss. Absorption of iron predominantly takes place in the duodenum.

Aplastic anaemia (Option C): The causes of aplastic anaemia often involve exposure to chemicals and drugs, such as chemotherapy agents and benzene, which suppress marrow in a dose-related and reversible manner. It can also be due to idiopathic causes or acquired stem cell defects.

Hemolytic anaemia (Option D): Hemolytic anaemias are characterised by a reduced lifespan of red blood cells, which leads to elevated erythropoietin levels and compensatory erythropoiesis. Clinically, they present with anaemia, jaundice, and splenomegaly due to increased red cell destruction, while intravascular hemolysis additionally produces hemoglobinemia, hemoglobinuria, and hemosiderinuria. Excess bilirubin from ongoing hemolysis contributes to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, and persistent cases may result in gallstone formation from heme pigment deposits.

questions.text: Which of the following, if given in large volumes, can lead to hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Among the given options, normal saline, if given in large volumes, can lead to hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis.

  • Large-volume administration of normal saline can result in hyperchloremic non-anion gap metabolic acidosis.
  • This occurs because under normal conditions, chloride and bicarbonate levels rise or fall in opposite directions to preserve electrical balance.
  • Severe acidosis may impair heart function, reduce responsiveness to inotropic agents, alter metabolism, enzyme activity, and coagulation, though some argue it enhances oxygen unloading from haemoglobin and may be preferable to alkalosis.
  • Despite theoretical risks, clinical evidence shows that induced hyperchloremic acidosis has little impact, and it is distinct from lactic or hypovolemic acidosis.
  • The composition of commonly used intravenous fluids is summarised in the table given below.

Explanation of other options:

Dextrose in NS (DNS) (Option A): DNS is not usually given in large volumes and hence unlikely to cause hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis.

5% dextrose in water (Option C): Since 5% dextrose does not contain chloride, it does not lead to hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis.

Ringer's lactate (Option D): Ringer's lactate is associated with the development of metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: A patient presents with bleeding symptoms and factor 9 deficiency that resolve afteradministration of a vitamin K injection. Which of the following is the most likely underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely underlying condition, among the options, that can cause factor 9 deficiency, reversible with vitamin K injection, is biliary obstruction.

  • Vitamin K exists in two natural forms: vitamin K1 (phylloquinone) from plants and vitamin K1 (menaquinones) synthesised by intestinal bacteria and found in hepatic tissue.
  • It is essential for the post-translational γ-carboxylation of glutamic acid residues in clotting factors (II, VII, IX, X) and proteins C, S, osteocalcin, and matrix Gla protein, enabling calcium binding.
  • Warfarin blocks this activation by preventing the conversion of vitamin K to its hydroquinone form.
  • Dietary sources include leafy green vegetables, liver, margarine, and oils such as olive, canola, and soybean.
  • Deficiency leads to hemorrhagic manifestations. Newborns are especially prone due to low stores, limited placental transfer, a sterile gut, and low breast milk vitamin K.
  • Intracranial, gastrointestinal, or skin bleeding may occur within the first week of life; hence, prophylactic vitamin K is routinely given at birth.
  • Adults may develop a deficiency with chronic intestinal disease, biliary obstruction, bowel resection, or broad-spectrum antibiotic use, which reduces gut flora.
  • Biliary obstruction causes defective enterohepatic circulation, which impairs the absorption of fat-soluble vitamins such as vitamin K. This leads to features of deficiency of clotting factors 2, 7, 9, and 10, which can be corrected with vitamin K administration.
  • Chronic liver disorders, including primary biliary cirrhosis, can lead to depletion of vitamin K reserves.
  • In vitamin K deficiency, the earliest and most frequent laboratory finding is a prolonged prothrombin time (PT), due to the short half-life of factor VII, and this occurs before changes in aPTT.
  • Administering 10 mg of vitamin K parenterally is usually sufficient to normalise clotting factor levels within 8-10 hours.
  • Assessment involves serum phylloquinone levels and detection of undercarboxylated prothrombin (PIVKA-II).
  • Elevated prothrombin time or clotting defects may indicate a deficiency, but are not very sensitive.
  • Treatment is usually parenteral vitamin K (10 mg), with oral or parenteral supplementation (1-2 mg daily or weekly) for malabsorption.
  • In liver disease, prolonged prothrombin time may persist despite supplementation, indicating impaired synthesis rather than deficiency.

Explanation of other options:

Haemophilia B(Option A): Haemophilia B arises due to a deficiency of clotting factor 9, which is treated using factor replacement.

Pernicious anaemia (Option C): Pernicious anaemia is the most common cause of vitamin B12 deficiency and is not associated with factor 9 deficiency.

Hepatitis A (Option D): Hepatocyte failure can lead to reduced synthesis of clotting factors, which will not be resolved with a vitamin K injection.

questions.text: A child presents with elevated concentrations of phenylalanine. Phenylalanine hydroxylase activity is found to be normal. Which of the following coenzymes, also required for tyrosine metabolism, could be deficient in this child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Phenylketonuria (PKU) is the most frequent inherited disorder of amino acid metabolism, and is an autosomal recessive disease caused by mutations in the gene encoding phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH).
  • The defect leads to hyperphenylalaninemia, where phenylalanine accumulates at levels up to ten times higher than normal in blood, urine, and tissues.
  • Because PAH normally converts phenylalanine into tyrosine, tyrosine becomes deficient. Management involves dietary restriction of phenylalanine and supplementation with tyrosine.
  • In some cases, PKU results from defects in enzymes needed for the synthesis or recycling of tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4), an essential cofactor for PAH, tyrosine hydroxylase, and tryptophan hydroxylase.
  • These deficiencies not only elevate phenylalanine but also impair neurotransmitter synthesis, leading to neurological problems.
  • Treatment may include BH4 supplementation and replacement with L-DOPA and 5-hydroxytryptophan to compensate for neurotransmitter deficiencies.
  • Additional features of PKU include the buildup of phenylalanine metabolites such as phenylpyruvate, phenyllactate, and phenylacetate, which give urine a musty or mousy odour.
  • Neurological manifestations in untreated cases include severe intellectual disability, developmental delay, seizures, and microcephaly, with IQ rarely exceeding 50.
  • Hypopigmentation is also common due to reduced tyrosine availability for melanin synthesis, resulting in fair hair, light skin, and blue eyes.
  • Diagnosis relies on newborn screening programs, as early detection is essential for treatment. Because infants may initially appear normal due to maternal clearance of phenylalanine during pregnancy, testing is typically performed 24–48 hours after protein feeding to avoid false negatives.
  • Treatment focuses on maintaining blood phenylalanine levels near normal through synthetic amino acid formulas free of phenylalanine, supplemented with selected low-phenylalanine natural foods.
  • Early initiation of treatment within the first week to ten days of life is critical to prevent intellectual impairment.
  • Lifelong restriction of phenylalanine is advised, and aspartame (a source of phenylalanine) should be avoided.

Explanation of other options:

Pyridoxal phosphate (Option B): Pyridoxal phosphate, the active form of vitamin B6, functions as a coenzyme in amino acid metabolism, particularly in transamination and decarboxylation reactions, and also serves as a cofactor for glycogen phosphorylase. It plays a role in steroid hormone regulation by detaching hormone–receptor complexes from DNA, thereby terminating hormonal action. In vitamin B6 deficiency, there is heightened sensitivity to even low levels of estrogens, androgens, cortisol, and vitamin D.

Adenosylcobalamin (Option C): Deficiency of adenosylcobalamin, also known as vitamin B12, causes megaloblastic anaemia. It is not involved in phenylalanine metabolism.

Tetrahydrofolic acid (Option D): The active form of folic acid is tetrahydrofolate, and its lack can lead to megaloblastic anaemia.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presents to the OPD for evaluation of a subcutaneous xanthoma on his right elbow. His father recently died of a myocardial infarction, and there is a family history of similar findings. Laboratory investigations reveal total cholesterol of 480 mg/dL, triglycerides of 146 mg/dL, and LDL cholesterol of 300 mg/dL. Which of the following types of Familial hyperlipoproteinemias is the most likely underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely underlying familial hypercholesterolemia in a patient with subcutaneous xanthoma, elevated cholesterol and LDL, with normal triglycerides and a positive family history of cardiovascular events is familial hyperlipoproteinemia type IIa.

The various hyperlipoproteinemias are summarised in the table given below.

Explanations of other options:

Type I (Option A): Familial lipoprotein lipase deficiency (Type I), a form of hyperlipoproteinemia, is characterised by markedly elevated triglyceride levels due to absent or defective lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activity or a deficiency of apo C-II, which inactivates LPL. Patients typically show reduced levels of both low-density lipoproteins (LDL) and high-density lipoproteins (HDL), yet despite the lipid abnormalities, there is no associated increase in the risk of coronary artery disease.

Type IIb (Option C): Type IIb hyperlipoproteinemia is a multifactorial and more common form of hypercholesterolemia compared to type IIa, characterised by elevation of both LDL and VLDL. This pattern significantly increases the risk of atherosclerosis and coronary heart disease.

Type III (Option D): Familial type III hyperlipoproteinemia, also called Familial type III hyperlipoproteinemia, also called remnant removal disease or dysbetalipoproteinemia, occurs due to defective clearance of lipoprotein remnants by the liver, caused by an apo E abnormality. This results in accumulation of chylomicron and VLDL remnants (β-VLDL), leading to hypercholesterolemia, xanthomas, and atherosclerosis.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with a fracture following trivial trauma. He also has perifollicular haemorrhages, lusterless hair, and dry skin. He is on an exclusive diet of toast and buns and has microcytic hypochromic anaemia. Which of the following enzymes is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above clinical picture paints a picture of a patient with scurvy in which Prolyl hydroxylase activity is affected, as it requires ascorbic acid as a cofactor.

  • Prolyl hydroxylase is responsible for hydroxylating proline residues in collagen, a modification that provides rigidity to the collagen molecule.
  • This enzyme requires ascorbic acid as a cofactor, and in its absence, the activity of both prolyl and lysyl hydroxylases is reduced, leading to defective collagen synthesis.
  • The patient's perifollicular haemorrhages, fragile and lusterless hair, and dry skin are explained by weakened collagen support of blood vessels and connective tissue, while his diet lacking vitamin C underlies the enzyme deficiency.
  • The poor collagen structure also contributes to impaired wound healing.
  • Vitamin C helps improve the absorption of inorganic iron in the gut, so higher intake can be useful.
  • For this reason, it is often prescribed alongside iron supplements in the management of iron deficiency anaemia.
  • Rich dietary sources include citrus fruits, broccoli, tomatoes, and potatoes.
  • Factors like smoking (even secondhand), dialysis, pregnancy, breastfeeding, and stress (such as infection or trauma) increase the body's need for vitamin C.
  • Deficiency leads to scurvy and is most often seen in the poor, elderly, alcoholics consuming under 10 mg daily, and young adults with severely unbalanced diets.

Explanation of other options:

ALA synthase (Option B): ALA synthase 2 deficiency, seen in X-linked sideroblastic anaemia, leads to reduced heme synthesis and presents clinically with anaemia. Laboratory findings show decreased red blood cell counts and lowered haemoglobin levels.

Glutathione peroxidase (Option C): Glutathione peroxidase is a selenium-dependent enzyme that detoxifies lipid peroxides and other hydroperoxides by converting them into less harmful fatty acids, using reduced glutathione as a cofactor. A deficiency impairs this protective mechanism, allowing lipid peroxides to accumulate in membranes and plasma lipoproteins, which increases oxidative stress and damages cell structures.

Dihydrofolate reductase (Option D): Dihydrofolate reductase is essential for regenerating tetrahydrofolate, which provides one-carbon units for DNA synthesis. Deficiency or inhibition of this enzyme disrupts thymidylate production, impairing DNA formation and particularly affecting rapidly dividing cells. This underlies the mechanism of drugs such as methotrexate, trimethoprim, and pyrimethamine, which target the enzyme for cancer therapy, antibacterial, or antimalarial purposes.

questions.text: A 7-month-old infant presents with developmental delay, seizures, and a cherry-red spot on fundoscopy. The mother has a history of an abortion at 8 weeks. Genetic testing reveals a deficiency of hexosaminidase A. Which of the following accumulates in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the clinical vignette of developmental delay, seizures, and cherry red spot, along with genetic testing revealing hexosaminidase A deficiency, the most likely diagnosis is Tay-Sachs disease, in which GM2 ganglioside accumulates.

  • Sphingolipidoses, a group of inherited lipid storage disorders, result from genetic defects in the breakdown of sphingosine-containing lipids.
  • These conditions share common features:
    • Accumulation of ceramide-containing complex lipids in cells, especially neurons, leads to neurodegeneration and reduced lifespan.
    • Normal synthesis of the stored lipids
    • Enzymatic defects affecting sphingolipid degradation in lysosomes
    • Uniformly reduced enzyme activity across tissues.
  • Effective treatments are limited, though some benefit has been seen with enzyme replacement therapy and bone marrow transplantation in disorders like Gaucher and Fabry disease.
  • Other emerging strategies include substrate reduction therapy, chemical chaperone therapy, and experimental gene therapy.

The various sphingolipidoses are summarised in the table given below.

Explanation of other options:

GM1 ganglioside (Option A): GM1 ganglioside, a derivative of GM3, is clinically important because it serves as the receptor in the human intestine for cholera toxin, enabling the toxin's pathogenic effects.

Galactocerebroside (Option C): Galactocerebroside, also known as galactosylceramide, is accumulated in Krabbe disease, which arises due to a deficiency of β-Galactosidase.

Sphingomyelin (Option D): Sphingomyelin is accumulated in Niemann-Pick disease caused by sphingomyelinase deficiency.

questions.text: A boy presents with orange-colored tonsils and a family history of multiple cardiovascular-related deaths. Laboratory investigations show total cholesterol of 80 mg/dL, triglycerides 146 mg/dL, HDL <5 mg/dL, and LDL 90 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis in this scenario, with orange-colored tonsils, family history of multiple cardiovascular deaths, and the given lipid profile, is suggestive of Tangier disease.

  • Tangier disease is a rare autosomal recessive disorder that can manifest as:
    • Asymmetric mononeuropathies
    • Slowly progressive polyneuropathy mainly affecting the legs
    • Pseudo-syringomyelia pattern with selective sensory loss.
  • Patients may also show enlarged yellow-orange tonsils as shown below, splenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy.
  • The condition results from mutations in the ABCA1 gene, leading to very low HDL cholesterol and elevated triacylglycerol levels.
  • Nerve biopsies demonstrate axonal degeneration with cycles of demyelination and remyelination, while electron microscopy shows lipid buildup in Schwann cells, particularly around unmyelinated and small myelinated fibres.
  • Currently, there is no specific treatment.

Explanation:

Niemann-Pick disease type C (Option A): Niemann-Pick disease type C is a progressive neurological disorder caused by mutations in the NPC1 or NPC2 genes, which disrupt lysosomal transport of cholesterol and certain sphingolipids. Although it may initially present with liver or spleen involvement, its main feature is gradual central nervous system deterioration over one to two decades.

Abetalipoproteinemia (Option C): Abetalipoproteinemia is a rare disorder caused by defective loading of apo B with lipid, which prevents the formation of chylomicrons, VLDL, and LDL. Affected individuals have very low blood acylglycerols and experience fat malabsorption along with fat accumulation in the intestine and liver. Without treatment, it may lead to early death. However, supplementation with fat-soluble vitamins, especially vitamin E, can prevent severe outcomes.

Familial lipoprotein lipase deficiency I(Option D): Familial lipoprotein lipase deficiency (Type I) arises from defective or absent lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activity, often due to LPL abnormalities or lack of apo C-II. This leads to impaired clearance of chylomicrons and VLDL, resulting in markedly elevated triglycerides with reduced LDL and HDL levels, but it does not increase coronary artery risk.
